chapters.title: # Setup - Starter Code
chapters.contentMd: # Setup - Starter Code To complete this lab you can either continue on with your solution from Lab 02 (CoffeeMate.2.0) or download the previous solution here [CoffeeMate.3.0.Starter](archives/CoffeeMate.3.0.Starter.zip) To open this in Android Studio, first extract the archive somewhere on your hard drive and select 'File->Open' etc. Once you open/import the CoffeeMate.3.0 Project you'll probably need to 'Clean & Build' the project to fix any residual errors. Next, go ahead and create 2 new Empty Activities - Favourites and - Search and name the layouts appropriately (as we've done previously). Don't forget to set their Base class as 'Base'. Next, replace your 'favourites' layout with this (you'll need to add a new 'red' color resource yourself) ~~~xml ~~~ and your 'search' layout with this ~~~xml ~~~ Run your app to confirm you can now load the 'search' and 'favourites' screens. If you can't, try and work out why. To point you in the right direction you may need to wire up the buttons on the layout to the relevant method in your Home.java which can be done like so ![](img/onclick.png) Notice how the method is already listed as it's being picked up from the associated Activity. Run the app again to confirm. Next, create a new java class called CoffeeFilter in the 'adapters' package and replace it with the following ~~~java public class CoffeeFilter extends Filter { public List originalCoffeeList; public String filterText; public CoffeeListAdapter adapter; public CoffeeFilter(List originalCoffeeList, String filterText, CoffeeListAdapter adapter) { super(); this.originalCoffeeList = originalCoffeeList; this.filterText = filterText; this.adapter = adapter; } public void setFilter(String filterText) { this.filterText = filterText; } @Override protected FilterResults performFiltering(CharSequence prefix) { FilterResults results = new FilterResults(); List newCoffees; String coffeeName; if (prefix == null || prefix.length() == 0) { newCoffees = new ArrayList<>(); if (filterText.equals("all")) { results.values = originalCoffeeList; results.count = originalCoffeeList.size(); } else { if (filterText.equals("favourites")) { for (Coffee c : originalCoffeeList) if (c.favourite) newCoffees.add(c); } results.values = newCoffees; results.count = newCoffees.size(); } } else { String prefixString = prefix.toString().toLowerCase(); newCoffees = new ArrayList<>(); for (Coffee c : originalCoffeeList) { coffeeName = c.coffeeName.toLowerCase(); if (coffeeName.contains(prefixString)) { if (filterText.equals("all")) { newCoffees.add(c); } else if (c.favourite) { newCoffees.add(c); }}} results.values = newCoffees; results.count = newCoffees.size(); } return results; } @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") @Override protected void publishResults(CharSequence prefix, FilterResults results) { adapter.coffeeList = (ArrayList) results.values; if (results.count >= 0) adapter.notifyDataSetChanged(); else { adapter.notifyDataSetInvalidated(); adapter.coffeeList = originalCoffeeList; } } } ~~~ and finally, create a new 'Blank' Fragment called SearchFragment in the 'fragments' package with the following settings : ![](img/blankfragment.png) Once the initial setup is complete your CoffeeMate 3.0 Project in Android Studio should looks as follows: ![](img/starter.3.png) Take a few moments to familiarise yourself with the new classes in your project and explore the resources and layouts that you will be referring to throughout the lab, especially the new layouts in both 'Design' view and 'Text' view. It's also probably a good idea to run the App at this stage too, so you can set up your AVD (if you haven't done so already) and confirm that the starter app is configured properly and running (although 'Search' and 'Favourites' don't really do anything). In this lab, you are required to do the following: - Display a list of the users 'Favourite' Coffees, highlighting the best 'rated' coffee - Allow Coffees in the list to be filtered on their type and name and rating. The following steps will guide you through these requirements, so we'll start with refactoring the necessary classes.

chapters.title: # CoffeeMate 3.0 - A First Look
# Reusing Fragments - 'Search' & Favourites'
chapters.contentMd: # Reusing Fragments - 'Search' & Favourites' If you recall in CoffeeMate 2.0 we used a Fragment to display our list of coffees inside our Home Screen. A Fragments main purpose is to be reused, so we can use our existing Fragment in both our Search & Favourites Screens. #Search & Favourites Screens The first thing we'll do is add the Fragment to our Search.java and Favourites.java Activity classes. This is pretty straightforward as we have already done this in our Home.java in CoffeeMate 2.0. ~~~java coffeeFragment = CoffeeFragment.newInstance(); //get a new Fragment instance getFragmentManager() .beginTransaction() .replace(R.id.fragment_container, coffeeFragment) .commit(); // add/replace in the current activity ~~~ You can literally cut & paste the above code into both activity classes onResume() method and run the app, so see what you get? And don't forget you can use Android Studio's tools for overriding methods (Here's another way to do it) ![](img/lab0405a.png) and then ![](img/lab0405b.png) You should be seeing something like the following : ![](img/searchlist.png) ![](img/favouriteslist.png) If you're seeing the "empty coffees" message behind the list, have a look at your Home.java and see if you can fix that? Obviously, our Favourites isn't filtered to show just 'Favourite Coffees' (we'll get to that later), but this does really illustrate the benefits of using Fragments when we can. See if you can edit and/or delete coffees? The next step is introducing the Filter so the user can view their Favourite Coffees (and eventually search).
